					Solar Glass

					
					Posted in P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive, Solar Glass on January 13, 2010|
													Leave a Comment »											

				


				
					

SCHOTT

www.schott.com

In addition to generating energy, ASI® Glass modules for architectural solutions provide several functions for modern solar architecture. Both opaque laminates (ASI® OPAK) and semitransparent laminates or double-glazing (ASI® THRU) meet the requirements of the building industry and can therefore be used with several traditional metal structure systems. Successfully used for more than 15 years, a comprehensive product range is available today: from standard formats to specific superstructures.

			

			
								Read Full Post »

				

							


		
			
				
					LC SmartGlass

					
					Posted in LC SmartGlass, P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive on January 13, 2010|
													Leave a Comment »											

				


				
					

SCHOTT

www.schott.com

Activating an on/off-switch turns the LC SmartGlass opaque into transparent. Design options include screens, energy-saving windows, bath / shower partitions, privacy screens, overhead lighting etc. It is also suited for use in technical applications like projection displays.

When turned off, the liquid crystal molecules assume random positions so that they scatter incident light and the LC SmartGlass becomes non-transparent (opaque).

When turned on, the liquid crystal molecules align and the LC SmartGlass turns transparent.


		
	
					Read Full Post »

				

							


		
			
				
					“Design and the Elastic Mind” _ Monocoque

					
					Posted in Monocoque, P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive on January 13, 2010|
													Leave a Comment »											

				


				
					

Neri Oxman  |  MIT

www.materialecology.com

Monocoque (French for *single shell*) stands for a construction technique that supports structural load using an object’s external skin. This stands in contrast with using an internal framework (or truss) that is then covered with a non-load-bearing skin. The project demonstrates the notion of a structural skin using a voronoi pattern, the density of which corresponds to multi-scalar loading conditions. The distribution of shear-stress lines and surface pressure is embodied in the allocation and relative thickness of the vein-like elements built into the skin. The composite prototype models represent three strategies for the design and fabrication of single shell structures. The component prototype model was 3-D printed using the Polyjet matrix technology which allows for the assignment of structural properties to multiple 3-D printed substances. This is the first design to utilize the technology.

					Read Full Post »

				

							


		
			
				
					Deformation & Shape Control of Space Structures

					
					Posted in P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive, Space Structures on January 13, 2010|
													Leave a Comment »											

				


				
					

FUKUNAGA Lab  |  Department of Aerospace Engineering, TOHOKU University

“Space Antennas are needed to keep their own shape with high accuracy against external disturbance or temperature change. Besides, Space Truss Structures are needed to suppress vibration due to dynamic external disturbance.

Shape control or vibration control are indispensable techniques for space structures. We have studied the optimal placement of sensors and actuators for the deformation and shape control of large-scale space structures. The results obtained through this research can realize the automatic and real-time control of space structures, and sharply improve their safety and reliability.

We have also studied the optimal topology or the optimal shape for adaptive structures like deployable truss structures or variable geometry truss (VGT).”

– Space Structures Laboratory, FUKUNAGA Lab

					Read Full Post »

				

							


		
			
				
					Emergent Surface

					
					Posted in Emergent Surface, P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive on January 13, 2010|
													Leave a Comment »											

				


				
					

Adaptive Building Initiative  |  Museum of Modern Art, New York

www.adaptivebuildings.com/emergent-surface.html

Based on new technologies for adaptive building skins, Emergent Surface is a wall that continuously reconfigures itself—portions selectively disappearing and reappearing. In one condition, the piece appears as a solid surface with three-dimensional curvature. In another, it resolves itself into seven slender poles running floor to ceiling. And between these extremes lie an infinite variety of configurations.

The sculpture, designed by Hoberman Associates, utilizes the Adaptive Building Initiative’s Linear Shading System as a means to transform. This commission represented a significant advance in research and development of the Linear Shading System and was the first structure to physically demonstrate its capabilities.

					Read Full Post »

				

							


		
			
				
					Linear Shading System

					
					Posted in Linear Shading System, P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive on January 13, 2010|
													Leave a Comment »											

				


				
					

Nikken Sekkei + Yasuda Atelier  |  Adaptive Building Initiative

www.adaptivebuildings.com/city-of-justice.html

The new Campus of Justice in Madrid is the largest single site dedicated to law courts in Europe. Following the master plan, Foster + Partners has designed two distinct circular buildings, Tribunal Superior de Justicia (High Court) and Audiencia Provincial (Appeals Court). Both buildings have been designed to minimize unwanted solar gain, while allowing natural daylight inside. As a key part of this environmental strategy, ABI systems were used to develop a customized shading scheme. Within the Audiencia Provincial, the shading units will occupy the central circular atrium as well as the eight peripheral atria. For Tribunal Superior de Justicia, the shading units will occupy the trapezoidal central atrium.

Each building will use ABI’s Linear Shading System ; when extended, the system will cover the triangulated roof grid. When retracted, their profile will ‘disappear’ into the structural profile of the roof. During the day, the primary function of the system will be sun shading. A custom algorithm combining historic solar gain data with real-time light-level sensing will control the shading units.

					Read Full Post »

				

							


		
			
				
					POLA Ginza Building Facade

					
					Posted in Ginza Building Facade, P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive on January 13, 2010|
													Leave a Comment »											

				


				
					

Nikken Sekkei + Yasuda Atelier  |  Adaptive Building Initiavie

www.adaptivebuildings.com/pola-ginza.html

The Adaptive Building Initiative and Hoberman Associates were commissioned by POLA, a Japanese cosmetics manufacturer, to develop an adaptive shading system for its new showroom building in Tokyo’s Ginza district. This system has been developed in collaboration with design architect Yasuda Atelier and executive architect Nikken Sekkei.

The 14-story building, which opened in October 2009, has about 185 shutter mechanisms that are housed within the double glazing of the façade. Each shutter has dimensions of approximately one by three meters, and is made of an acrylic sheet that has been formed into a curved surface.

					Read Full Post »

				

							


		
			
				
					Adaptive Fritting

					
					Posted in Adaptive Fritting, P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive on January 13, 2010|
													Leave a Comment »											

				


				
					

Adaptive Building Initiative

www.adaptivebuildings.com/adaptive-fritting.html

The Adaptive Building Initiative, with design assistance from Hoberman Associates, created a dynamic installation for Harvard University Graduate School of Design based on ABI’s original invention, Adaptive Fritting. As with standard fritted glass, adaptive fritting utilizes a graphic pattern in order to control heat gain and to modulate light, while allowing sufficient transparency for viewing.

While conventional fritting relies on a fixed pattern, adaptive fritting provides a surface controllable transparency that can modulate between opaque and transparent states. This performance is achieved by shifting a series of fritted glass layers so that the graphic pattern alternately aligns and diverges.

The installation at Gund Hall consists of six motorized panels comprising a 24-foot by 4-foot window, housed within a curved wall. These panels are programmed to form a dynamic field where light transmission, views, and enclosure continuously adapt and change. As the panels transform, the visual effect is of sparse dots blossoming into an opaque surface.

					Read Full Post »

			<div class="post-81 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-p1-1_typologies-adaptive category-solar-glass" id="post-81">
				<div class="posttitle">
					<h2><a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/solar-glass/" rel="bookmark" target="_blank">Solar Glass</a></h2>

					<p class="post-info">
					Posted in <a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/category/p1-1_typologies-adaptive/" rel="category tag" target="_blank">P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive</a>, <a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/category/p1-1_typologies-adaptive/solar-glass/" rel="category tag" target="_blank">Solar Glass</a> on January 13, 2010|
													<a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/solar-glass/#respond" target="_blank">Leave a Comment »</a>											</p>

				</div>


				<div class="entry">
					<p><strong><a href="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/solar-glass.jpg" target="_blank"><img data-attachment-id="82" data-permalink="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/solar-glass/solar-glass/" data-orig-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/solar-glass.jpg" data-orig-size="1208,770" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta='{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":""}' data-image-title="Solar Glass" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/solar-glass.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/solar-glass.jpg?w=500" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-82" title="Solar Glass" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/solar-glass.jpg?w=500" alt=""></a></strong></p>

<p><strong>SCHOTT</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.schott.com" target="_blank">www.schott.com</a></p>

<p>In addition to generating energy, ASI® Glass modules for architectural solutions provide several functions for modern solar architecture. Both opaque laminates (ASI® OPAK) and semitransparent laminates or double-glazing (ASI® THRU) meet the requirements of the building industry and can therefore be used with several traditional metal structure systems. Successfully used for more than 15 years, a comprehensive product range is available today: from standard formats to specific superstructures.</p>

			<div id="atatags-26942-65a1cdbec7cf6"></div>

			
								<p><a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/solar-glass/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to Solar Glass" target="_blank">Read Full Post »</a></p>

				</div>

							</div>


		
			<div class="post-78 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-lc-smartglass category-p1-1_typologies-adaptive" id="post-78">
				<div class="posttitle">
					<h2><a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/lc-smartglass/" rel="bookmark" target="_blank">LC SmartGlass</a></h2>

					<p class="post-info">
					Posted in <a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/category/p1-1_typologies-adaptive/lc-smartglass/" rel="category tag" target="_blank">LC SmartGlass</a>, <a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/category/p1-1_typologies-adaptive/" rel="category tag" target="_blank">P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive</a> on January 13, 2010|
													<a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/lc-smartglass/#respond" target="_blank">Leave a Comment »</a>											</p>

				</div>


				<div class="entry">
					<p><strong><a href="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/lc-smartglass.jpg" target="_blank"><img data-attachment-id="79" data-permalink="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/lc-smartglass/lc-smartglass/" data-orig-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/lc-smartglass.jpg" data-orig-size="634,424" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta='{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":""}' data-image-title="LC SmartGlass" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/lc-smartglass.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/lc-smartglass.jpg?w=500" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-79" title="LC SmartGlass" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/lc-smartglass.jpg?w=500&h=334" alt="" width="500" height="334"></a></strong></p>

<p><strong>SCHOTT</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.schott.com" target="_blank">www.schott.com</a></p>

<p>Activating an on/off-switch turns the LC SmartGlass opaque into transparent. Design options include screens, energy-saving windows, bath / shower partitions, privacy screens, overhead lighting etc. It is also suited for use in technical applications like projection displays.</p>

<p>When turned off, the liquid crystal molecules assume random positions so that they scatter incident light and the LC SmartGlass becomes non-transparent (opaque).</p>

<p>When turned on, the liquid crystal molecules align and the LC SmartGlass turns transparent.</p>

	</div>

			<div class="post-72 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-monocoque category-p1-1_typologies-adaptive" id="post-72">
				<div class="posttitle">
					<h2><a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/design-and-the-elastic-mind-_-monocoque/" rel="bookmark" target="_blank">“Design and the Elastic Mind” _ Monocoque</a></h2>

					<p class="post-info">
					Posted in <a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/category/p1-1_typologies-adaptive/monocoque/" rel="category tag" target="_blank">Monocoque</a>, <a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/category/p1-1_typologies-adaptive/" rel="category tag" target="_blank">P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive</a> on January 13, 2010|
													<a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/design-and-the-elastic-mind-_-monocoque/#respond" target="_blank">Leave a Comment »</a>											</p>

				</div>


				<div class="entry">
					<p><a href="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/neri-oxman.jpg" target="_blank"><img data-attachment-id="73" data-permalink="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/design-and-the-elastic-mind-_-monocoque/neri-oxman/" data-orig-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/neri-oxman.jpg" data-orig-size="2154,844" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta='{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":""}' data-image-title="Neri Oxman" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/neri-oxman.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/neri-oxman.jpg?w=500" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-73" title="Neri Oxman" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/neri-oxman.jpg?w=500&h=195" alt="" width="500" height="195"></a></p>

<p><strong>Neri Oxman  |  MIT</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.materialecology.com" target="_blank">www.materialecology.com</a></p>

<p>Monocoque (French for *single shell*) stands for a construction technique that supports structural load using an object’s external skin. This stands in contrast with using an internal framework (or truss) that is then covered with a non-load-bearing skin. The project demonstrates the notion of a structural skin using a voronoi pattern, the density of which corresponds to multi-scalar loading conditions. The distribution of shear-stress lines and surface pressure is embodied in the allocation and relative thickness of the vein-like elements built into the skin. The composite prototype models represent three strategies for the design and fabrication of single shell structures. The component prototype model was 3-D printed using the Polyjet matrix technology which allows for the assignment of structural properties to multiple 3-D printed substances. This is the first design to utilize the technology.</p>

					<p><a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/design-and-the-elastic-mind-_-monocoque/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to “Design and the Elastic Mind” _ Monocoque" target="_blank">Read Full Post »</a></p>

				</div>

					<p><a href="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/emergent-surface.jpg" target="_blank"><img data-attachment-id="49" data-permalink="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/emergent-surface/emergent-surface-2/" data-orig-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/emergent-surface.jpg" data-orig-size="1099,658" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta='{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":""}' data-image-title="Emergent Surface" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/emergent-surface.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/emergent-surface.jpg?w=500" loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-49" title="Emergent Surface" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/emergent-surface.jpg?w=500&h=299" alt="" width="500" height="299"></a></p>

<p><strong>Adaptive Building Initiative  |  Museum of Modern Art, New York</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.adaptivebuildings.com/emergent-surface.html" target="_blank">www.adaptivebuildings.com/emergent-surface.html</a></p>

<p>Based on new technologies for adaptive building skins, Emergent Surface is a wall that continuously reconfigures itself—portions selectively disappearing and reappearing. In one condition, the piece appears as a solid surface with three-dimensional curvature. In another, it resolves itself into seven slender poles running floor to ceiling. And between these extremes lie an infinite variety of configurations.</p>

<p>The sculpture, designed by Hoberman Associates, utilizes the Adaptive Building Initiative’s Linear Shading System as a means to transform. This commission represented a significant advance in research and development of the Linear Shading System and was the first structure to physically demonstrate its capabilities.</p>

				<div class="entry">
					<p><a href="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/linear-shading-system_foster.jpg" target="_blank"><img data-attachment-id="34" data-permalink="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/linear-shading-system/linear-shading-system_foster/" data-orig-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/linear-shading-system_foster.jpg" data-orig-size="1459,685" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta='{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":""}' data-image-title="Linear Shading System_Foster" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/linear-shading-system_foster.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/linear-shading-system_foster.jpg?w=500" loading="lazy" class="size-full wp-image-34 alignnone" title="Linear Shading System_Foster" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/linear-shading-system_foster.jpg?w=500&h=234" alt="" width="500" height="234"></a><strong></strong></p>

<p><strong>Nikken Sekkei + Yasuda Atelier  |  Adaptive Building Initiative</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.adaptivebuildings.com/city-of-justice.html" target="_blank">www.adaptivebuildings.com/city-of-justice.html</a></p>

<p>The new Campus of Justice in Madrid is the largest single site dedicated to law courts in Europe. Following the master plan, Foster + Partners has designed two distinct circular buildings, Tribunal Superior de Justicia (High Court) and Audiencia Provincial (Appeals Court). Both buildings have been designed to minimize unwanted solar gain, while allowing natural daylight inside. As a key part of this environmental strategy, ABI systems were used to develop a customized shading scheme. Within the Audiencia Provincial, the shading units will occupy the central circular atrium as well as the eight peripheral atria. For Tribunal Superior de Justicia, the shading units will occupy the trapezoidal central atrium.</p>

<p>Each building will use ABI’s Linear Shading System ; when extended, the system will cover the triangulated roof grid. When retracted, their profile will ‘disappear’ into the structural profile of the roof. During the day, the primary function of the system will be sun shading. A custom algorithm combining historic solar gain data with real-time light-level sensing will control the shading units.</p>

<p>The Adaptive Building Initiative and Hoberman Associates were commissioned by POLA, a Japanese cosmetics manufacturer, to develop an adaptive shading system for its new showroom building in Tokyo’s Ginza district. This system has been developed in collaboration with design architect Yasuda Atelier and executive architect Nikken Sekkei.</p>

<p>The 14-story building, which opened in October 2009, has about 185 shutter mechanisms that are housed within the double glazing of the façade. Each shutter has dimensions of approximately one by three meters, and is made of an acrylic sheet that has been formed into a curved surface.</p>

			<div class="post-7 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-adaptive-fritting category-p1-1_typologies-adaptive" id="post-7">
				<div class="posttitle">
					<h2><a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/adaptive-fritting/" rel="bookmark" target="_blank">Adaptive Fritting</a></h2>

					<p class="post-info">
					Posted in <a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/category/p1-1_typologies-adaptive/adaptive-fritting/" rel="category tag" target="_blank">Adaptive Fritting</a>, <a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/category/p1-1_typologies-adaptive/" rel="category tag" target="_blank">P1.1_Typologies: Adaptive</a> on January 13, 2010|
													<a href="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/adaptive-fritting/#respond" target="_blank">Leave a Comment »</a>											</p>

				</div>


				<div class="entry">
					<p><a href="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/abi_adaptive_fritting_sequence3.jpg" target="_blank"><img data-attachment-id="25" data-permalink="https://arthurtseng.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/adaptive-fritting/abi_adaptive_fritting_sequence-4/" data-orig-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/abi_adaptive_fritting_sequence3.jpg" data-orig-size="1000,247" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta='{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":""}' data-image-title="ABI_Adaptive_Fritting_Sequence" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/abi_adaptive_fritting_sequence3.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/abi_adaptive_fritting_sequence3.jpg?w=500" loading="lazy" class="size-full wp-image-25 alignnone" title="ABI_Adaptive_Fritting_Sequence" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://arthurtseng.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/abi_adaptive_fritting_sequence3.jpg?w=500" alt=""></a></p>

<p><strong>Adaptive Building Initiative</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.adaptivebuildings.com/adaptive-fritting.html" target="_blank">www.adaptivebuildings.com/adaptive-fritting.html</a></p>

<p>The Adaptive Building Initiative, with design assistance from Hoberman Associates, created a dynamic installation for Harvard University Graduate School of Design based on ABI’s original invention, Adaptive Fritting. As with standard fritted glass, adaptive fritting utilizes a graphic pattern in order to control heat gain and to modulate light, while allowing sufficient transparency for viewing.</p>

<p>While conventional fritting relies on a fixed pattern, adaptive fritting provides a surface controllable transparency that can modulate between opaque and transparent states. This performance is achieved by shifting a series of fritted glass layers so that the graphic pattern alternately aligns and diverges.</p>

<p>The installation at Gund Hall consists of six motorized panels comprising a 24-foot by 4-foot window, housed within a curved wall. These panels are programmed to form a dynamic field where light transmission, views, and enclosure continuously adapt and change. As the panels transform, the visual effect is of sparse dots blossoming into an opaque surface.</p>
